text: If only there was a place as classic, good and cheap as Fiore's on every corner of this dang city. The subs are simple, tasty, not too heavy. Tucked inside of the neighborhood in Ukranian Village, the opposite of overwhelming spots deeper in West Town. They have all kinds of handmade stuff in the freezer as well. Come on guys, the "rude" service is part of the charm! At least it's quick!

Just moved to the area in June and have always wanted to stop in.  Well that was a mistake...Service is absolutely horrible from the manager..  Not sure how they can stay open by  giving the finger to every customer that walks in, since a hidden place like this can only survive on neighborhood people.

Love it. Great subs, they're ready for pick up 5 mins after I call in. Much better than vinnie's or bari's IMO. The lady and teen that ring me up are always very nice, she's especially pleasant. I never had the grumpy guy - I guess I've just been lucky.

I've resisted ever getting a yelp account because frankly, I think it can be misused. In the case of Fiores this one star is completely deserving.  The owner is the most dry and emotionless person.  He barely looks up from the counter or acknowledges his customers, and when he does it's snappy, and short tempered.  I've had multiple experiences with this guy, but figure maybe he's having a bad day or just doesn't care.  That's cool, I don't expect a song or dance for spending my money, but I also don't like to be made to feel like crap either.  In a day and age with technology and delivery access,  one would think a small deli/grocery business would be eager to provide old school manners to their customers and keep that tradition alive.  *On a positive note, not sure if guy who makes the sandwiches with tattoos still works there, but he was always very kind.*

Stopped in to have one of their delicious Italian subs, purchased it and an ice tea and went out to their patio to enjoy it there. Got up to go and the red metal lawn chair was stuck to my clothing, looked and I had red paint all over my new shorts on also on my shirt. Went in to tell the guy at the cash register what had happened, ............. he didn't seem very concerned that his furniture had ruined my clothing. In fact he didn't even apologize, barely looked at me and kinda said give us a call if it doesn't wash out. Well you tell me, what kind of red spray paint washes off clothing? If the fucking chairs are still wet and tacky why wouldn't you put a sign on them saying so, or even better yet close the patio. They really didn't give a shit, also seems to be how they treat most customers that they don't already know. Just avoid this place and their attitude.

Yesterday I just had the worst costumer experience at this place in of the guys was really disrespectful also told me and I quote "if you don like it get the f***k are here! And go somewhere else." To which I responded, this is how you treat your costumer also neighbor? "I don't give a f***k" he said.
Go to spot in UKV for real Italian subs.

Great neighborhood corner shop. The sandwiches are great, and everything else is nice to have at arm's length when you're not in the mood to cook after dinner. All is well priced, and they make a classic Italian style sub sandwich that rivals the best.  It's a Chicagoan's dream of mine to live near a classic Italian sub joint and now my dreams have come true, and the reality exceeds expectations.  Cheers to you Fiore's. Keep on doing the good mans work.
Great sandwiches and Italian specialties, bargain prices.
Great sandwiches, small selection of groceries, and they do awesome catering platters!

I came here and ordered their pepper and egg sandwich. I've definitely had way better from numerous places. What I did like about this place is that they make it fresh. I ordered it with cheese and hot peppers, but couldn't really tasty any cheese. Although they made it fresh, I felt it still lacked flavor and wasn't the tastiest I've tried. I do however like that it's small and in a neighborhood. I'll prob try a sandwich next time.

Phone call, 3:15: Me: Hi can I place an order for pickup? Fiores: No we close at 3. Me: Oh okay, your website says 4 pm. Fiores: I know that.  (Hangs up.)  Better way to go about that...but the food is damn good.

Had an Italian 10" sub...very happy with the outcome, good meat/cheese and the bread (d'amoto) was good too.   I generally hit Bari as it's been my go to for years/ but Fiore is blocks away from our new home so that's worth a lot of future visits to further explore their other offerings.
Old school place with great subs and very reasonable prices. Operators are super nice people. Highly recommended

Not only a Chicago 5... I give it a New York 5! Something about a real Italian making your Italian food can't be beat. Meatballs were delicious, beef combo was so good...  Best Italian sub I've had in Chicago. Cute, clean place.. excellent service.  Better than Bari in my opinion.

i do believe best authentic straight from italia mmmmmmmmm food!i lived in the neighborhood for forty five yrs and they are the best! i miss them alot!been all over america driving truck and drove construction 18 wheeler for 18 yrs and i do believe this food that mr mike fiore has is the best!

A good selection of sandwiches using very fresh ingredients. The Prosciutto with provalone was delicious!  Reasonable prices and the operators were attentive and friendly. The shop is in a small grocery store so it is a little tight. No seating that I saw. I'll be back the next time I am in the neighborhood.

I'm very sorry I had to fire my favorite sandwich today . How can you smoke a cigarette, move patio furniture, drink a bottled water and walk in and make a sandwich ? No hand washing ?! No gloves ?! No way ! Very sad because they have a nice menu and good value ! Sorry this is my last trip to Fiore's !!!!!

While this wasn't the Bari killer I was hoping for, it's a damn fine place to eat a sub sammie. Came by yesterday and did the meatball and the Italian, and split these with my wife.  Fantastic, great prices, clean storefront (even at Bari, I don't love standing inside the place), and a little patio out back that has four small tables so in the summer sun, you can take this puppy out back and make a mercy killing. I need to go back to both Bari and Fontano's to settle this debate once and for all!
A nice little Italian delicatessen. Out of the way, Yet great. Especially for their tangy artichoke salad.

Solid neighborhood Italian deli. Came here for the first time to try the Italian sub, the service was very quick and friendly. Sandwiches are priced extremely well. I would definitely recommend to anyone craving a great simple Italian sub sandwich and I will be back again.

I can't say anything bad about this place. It's perfect in every way. Friendly owners, great staff and most importantly amazing sandwiches packed with meat. When I'm feeling like cutting meat out of my life for a bit, I go with the fresh mozz basil tomato.  One tip though, if they added burrata to the menu that would be SICK!!! I just love burrata so... DO IT PLEASE!  ;)

A true Ukrainian Village classic! The West Loop has J.P. Graziano's. Noble Square has Bari. Little Italy has Fontano's. We have Fiore's. These are the only names you need to know when ordering Italian subs in Chicago. These guys have been around since my dad was a teenager, and once you bite into the sandwich, you can tell why. Delicious fresh bread, crisp vegetables, copious portion of delectable meat and cheese, and a crisp, not overpowering oil/vinegar finish. Friendly service and a cute little grocery, as well. And let's face it, you might as well get a footlong, because it'll only cost you $1.50 more than a sixer. Fiore's for life! Can't wait to stock my fantasy football wrap party next weekend with 3 giant party subs!

This is such a great neighborhood staple. Delicious sandwiches, deli meats, cheese, and sides, and even homemade Italian dinners you can take home and heat up. I highly recommend their breakfast sandwiches, great bang for the buck and just what you need on a lazy sunday morning after a late night. NICEST employees, very hard working and remember you even after one visit. GO HERE!

Great little Italian deli that's been around quite some time. I haven't been in the area in a long time and stopped in for a homemade meatball sandwich with cheese and house made giardinera. Very satisfying and tasty. The surprise of the visit was their homemade sausage pizza. Usually a thicker focacci style, but this one was thin.
It's so nice to find a local Italian deli and grocery store in the neighborhood. They have fantastic sandwiches, great pasta and all sorts of munchies. I love it! Can't wait to try something else.

DELICIOUS. Was at a friends place in Ukranian Village & we brought these in for lunch for a group of 10. Every single person was happy with their order. I got the smoked turkey which was fantastic. Note that the large sandwich is LARGE. Some of the other fan favorites were the combo & the meatball sub. This place also delivers, and apparently has amazing breakfast sandwiches- those are next on my list to try!

Great little neighborhood deli.  Best pepper and egg in the city, all breakfast sandwiches are great and cheap.  This place is a hidden gem, they have frozen meals you can bring home the lasagna is better than any top Italian restaurant in the city.  My only wish is they were close to my house.
Amazing sandwich at a great price. Great service. Friendly people. What more can you ask for. Highly recommend to everyone to visit and enjoy a sandwich :)

Great deli and exceptional customer service.  Sandwiches are delicious and are very reasonably priced.  Also bought some of their homemade frozen pasta, cooked it up and was impressed.  Check this hidden gem out- you won't be disappointed!

Best deli I've been to on the west side of Chicago. FANTASTIC sandwiches--very cheap but very fresh. The sandwich cost me $5.45 but it was more like a $10-12 sandwich in terms of its quality. Everything else in the deli looked very good and fresh. Not sure about the prices for other groceries, but the quality of the prepared foods/deli is outstanding, especially conserving the quality!
Solid little neighborhood Italian deli. Terrific roast beef sandwich. Nice to have around the corner. I hope it stays in business for a long time.

I've been here about 6-7 times. I live nearby and have wanted to love this place each time and forgave a lot of things each time. But, my last visit I realized I am borderline vehemently against this place for the following reasons. Their service: hostile, or not friendly at all. It's almost been like i was bothering them when I've ordered my sub. I've heard them be especially rude to some Eastern European contracting guys, repeating the same thing when they didn't understand, not bothering to slow down or help explain. Then have witnessed totally different attitudes in the same breath to those they know. This has been consistently the case and I think as a business owner, it's shitty. Regardless of how long you've been there. The fact that you sound like a dick or just flat every time I go in, when I'm always polite, is shitty. This has been 2 different guys behind the counter, one of them who seems to be the owner.  Price: more expensive than Bari, vinnie's or any of the other sub shops. Quality: really upset about this, the amount of meat they put in the sandwich is shameful, they crumple the cheese in, and the tomato is maybe a slice and a half that they cut up into tiny pieces. Each and every time. I also can't help but think they would put more in if I was Italian or someone they knew. I once asked for extra meat in a sub and it was really sad and they charged me $1.50 more for it.  I also bought some Parmesan behind the counter once and the guy cut me a piece that was 70% rind, it was so offensive. I didn't discover till I got home and I was honestly intimidated to go back and complain. It wasn't cut like a triangle, or square, it was cut like I ordered rind w some meat on it. They would've never done that to someone they knew or an Italian looking person.  If the service was better, then I could excuse the jack in price and the shitty sub, that I actually enjoy in a guilty pleasure way. But I don't enjoy being treated like a second class citizen, being handed a crappily put together sub and paying more than I should for it.  This attitude in handling business not only upsets me but it's just not how you treat human beings, let alone customers.

I travel to the neighborhood just so I can go to Fiore's!  The deli sandwiches are incredibly reasonable priced and almost too delicious.  Great little patio in the back to enjoy a summer day while dining on a sub and cannoli.

Love this place.  It's nice to have a good Italian deli in Ukrainian Villiage.  Frank and Sal are also chill and enjoyable to hang out with.  My go to is a prosciutto sub and tall boy Arizona green tea.  They also have amazing breakfast sandwiches.  I once also got an antipasto platter for a work event from here and it was a hit.

Just had a great Tuna Salad sandwich from Fiore's. Ingredients were fresh and took the sandwich to another level. Mustard, mayo, and giardiniera were the key to pairing with the soft flavors of the salad. Will definitely be going to this place anytime I get a craving for a great sub.

I moved into the neighborhood recently and thought that it was nice to be so close to a large grocery chain like Mariano's. Turns out, I have only been to Mariano's once. The majority of my shopping is done at small shops like this one. They have a lot to offer for such a small store. It kinda feels like a NY City deli cause of the variety of food products that they carry in such a small spot. The fresh sandwiches are delicious (come back in the morning for their pepper and egg breakfast sandwich). Everything that I've gotten from the freezer section is delicious. Their homemade giardiniera and everything behind the deli is amazing. The guys working are awesome. I feel like everytime i go there the gentleman gives me a free focaccia cause my order is so big. Love this place. Cant wait til summer time when i can eat on their back patio.

You will never eat an Italian sub from anywhere else! There is no reason to. This is the epitome of what an Italian sub should taste like. I got it with hot peppers but they have mild too. The 10" was perfect for me but it comes in four sizes. Try it! Overall, this place is a true Chicago-Italian family owned deli. Locals thrive off here. Homemade salads, Italian pastries, pastas, meatballs, etc. The owner and his son know locals by name and have been there for almost 45 years. You wouldn't find this place without looking but if you're reading this, you are looking and you have found a place with true Italian deli fare.

I had their 10" fresh mozzarella sub today. The bread was great, and the mozzarella and basil was fresh. I also couldn't help but notice how cheap the array of pasta salads are. I can't wait to try more! Staff is friendly, service is quick. A great little hidden neighborhood gem.
Awesome neighborhood spot. Sandwiches are great and pretty cheap. Plus there is a little grocery and homemade Italian meals in the freezer.

You might experience sticker shock at Fiore's as their sandwiches are DIRT cheap. Serving made to order subs featuring bread from D'amatos stuffed with top shelf ingredients, it's hard to believe anyone would ever drop money at a fast food restaurant.  It you're looking for some SOLID brunch options, try both the house special "peppers & egg", and the sausage egg & cheese subs. Packed with flavor, and coming in at a default 10" you'll be shocked to find they are only 5$ a pop. So much quality for such an affordable price.
Dang.  I miss this place.  Yes, the sub sandwich, the beef sandwich, and much more.

Neat little spot with good sandwiches. The meatball was very good and my friends really liked the Italian 8" sub. It's got a good, cramped, warm, family owned vibe that reminds me of visiting older italian relatives- gelato, italian cookies and multiple spots to buy nuttella - just good, old fashioned, nice, reasonable and uncommercial. Good spot. Try it if you are in the neighborhood.
Fiore's is the type of place that makes a neighborhood feel like a neighborhood.  Great made-to-order subs, friendly service and plenty of character.

love this place and the sandwitches, especially the fact that Sal makes the most awesome subs, everything he makes it's with love..he is truly a humble person..Sal keep being so wonderful....I suggest everyone trys a sub from Fiore, You won't be dissappoint :)

My friend brought me to order a sandwich since we were both a bit hungry. The Italian sub is a must. The Italian bread was nice and a bit oily but the meat and peppers made it worth the stop. And cannot forget to grab a cannoli. Staff was friendly.

I love Fiore's for being able to quickly run and grab the staples (butter, eggs, bread, milk) or to grab a quick sandwich (fresh mozzarella and prosciutto - the best!) Their stock of homepage pastas and various antipasti salads have also been total lifesavers when I have little time or inclination to make dinner. Ukrainian Village is very lucky to have this little gem.

okay, so I have only been once, and it was a brief visit on my way home. Stopped to pick up some meatballs to go with the lasagna rolls I made; the man said they were good. I got some lentil soup for my self and oooooohwheeeeeee was that one tasty bowl of soup. Wow. I got it from the deli and a cup was a 2 serving size portion for like $3; it was so excellent. The employees were HIGHLY pleasant; I will most def be back to try a sub.

OMG we love this Deli. Every time I walk in feels like I am transported back in time. I am created once I walk through the door. From a Italian / Chicago guy asking how I am doing. they have a great meet and cheese section and their sandwiches are amazing. I get the Italian while my GF gets the prosciutto. Love stopping in for a random meal.

Delicious and affordable Italian Subs. If not quite as good as Bari, it is clearly the nieghborhood best. Both the hot Italian and Tuna Subs are fairly priced (6$+tax for a 12 inch sub), and the execution is great. I don't recommend the frozen prepared foods. The homemade and then frozen Minestrone did not hold up when I reheated it.

I'm still drooling thinking about the cannoli. Fresh, creamy and delicious with just a hint of lemon. They were only $1.89 each - wish I'd bought two! I also got an 8" italian sub for under $5. It was so good, I ate both halves when I'd wanted to save it for another meal. This place could be scary addictive! A hidden Italian gem in the mostly eastern European neighborhood. I want to keep it a secret, so I don't have to share.

Had a pleasant experience with the gentleman making my sandwich,  the owner on the other hand was an asshole throwing my debit card, receipt and pen and throwing my copy of the receipt on the counter. Never will I suggest this place no matter how good or disgusting the food is.

Fiore's is one of those neighborhood gems you should drive across town to support.  In a market of chain groceries and delis like Subway, 7-Eleven, Wal-Mart, and Walgreen monopolizing the landscape with their ability to buy processed food at much cheaper prices, the mom and pop grocer / delis are a dying breed.  And don't save this one out of pity!  Support them because they produce good fresh food items at affordable prices!  How do they do it when so many others fail to do so without charging a small fortune?  The other neighborhood gems in nearby Wicker Park and Bucktown would charge double for the same prepared items if they actually made them on premises.   I've been coming here for years and have ordered half their menu.  Their turkey, tuna, and caprese subs are good and I LOVE the Italian Sub.  It's one of the best around.  I like adding  prosciutto to the caprese, and I should probably start asking for extra mozzarella.  Their meatball sandwich is awesome too.  The Italian & meatball are what I crave. I catered a small group outing and everyone loved the food.  A few of the long subs go a long way when cut into 3-4 inch sections, and are a crowd pleaser.  It was all boxed up with all the sides and condiments to serve with it.  The meat and cheese tray is plenty of good eating for a group of men, but I don't think I will order that again.  Especially if you already have subs, it just looks like a big tray of luncheon meats and cheeses that you already have on the sandwiches.  The big olive salad was tasty and a crowd pleaser too. I like getting the individual ravioli and lasagna servings for a quick hot lunch.  I love that they sell them in modest sizes at modest prices so that you don't have to stuff yourself silly just because you are craving some pasta carbs.  Where else can you find a good fresh lasagna fast without being forced to pig out on a huge plate?  And you can also pick up family sizes in the freezer section to easily server dinner to your whole family.  My family was happy when I brought that home, and they like the tomato bread I threw in for good measure that was also a good price.  They have frozen soups too.  I tried the chicken soup.  I thought it tasted just ok, but I still have faith to try the minestrone next time.  Even if the flavors are just ok, its not much more expensive than the canned soup from the store & doesn't have all those nasty chemicals & preservatives, so its still a good purchase.

As always Fiore's comes through. Had a party yesterday and they set us up with 2 3ft sandwiches with all the fixins on the side. Everyone loved the food and we can't thank the guys there enough for helping us out! Keep up the good work

Going for a run around your neighborhood has it's perks.  I never knew that just a few blocks and around the corner from me was this little gem.  I crave a true Italian sub now and then and I finally found a go-to deli that I can walk (or run) to.  A 1.5 foot sub cost a little under $10 - superb deal if you ask me.  Plus it tastes great!  They have a variety of cheese, pizza by the slice (this was pretty decent for $2.50), and gelato.  There's also a shaded patio in the back to eat your food.   Service is quick and friendly.   I'll definitely come back for gelato and of course for the subs.

Update: I have gone here everyday for the past week.. I have a problem.  You cant beat the Italian beef. Also, the deli subs are awesome.. 7$ for a 12' that would make subway go wee wee wee all the way home..  Someone in front of me got a combo sammy.. but not I-beef and sausage, it was I-beef and meatballs! Whoa, that rules.

Get the Italian Sub. JUST DO IT. Screw your cholesterol, YOLO!!! (just kidding, who says yolo anymore?)  But seriously, this sub is the best. One adorable thing they sell is a packed lunch for kids (mini sub, drink, etc). Any kid who is getting that for lunch on the regular is lucky.
Ditto to every single 5 star review written.  Love this place.

Fantastic sandwiches, accepts credit card, open early (7AM) to grab some lunch before heading to work. I have yet to try the frozen dinners or the pasta salads, I hear good things and they look delicious. Not to mention, they have just about the nicest employees ever. In short, I'm so happy this place is in my neighborhood.
Fantastic little ma n pa deli. They make breakfast sammies on d'amato's bread?!
Don't wanna over due it but this place is THE BEST!!!  Sammiches and paninis are killer and would put them up against any place in town. Much love fiores.  Oh and the breakfast sammies to.
Here's the short version of everyone else's reviews: - Go there to get great sandwiches and deli cuts - Pre-made frozen Italian dishes are good - You're rolling the dice on whatever's on the shelves

I stumbled on this place walking to work from the Western Ave. Metra Stop sometime in late 2010. This was very fortunate. This is an old school Chicago Italian deli. They have extremely high quality ingredients. People come here to buy deli items to take home. The meats and cheeses are a much better deal than you can get at supermarket counters or even prepackaged. They have fantastic prosciutto at about half the price you can find anywhere else. You can get frozen pasta and sauces in the freezer case. You can also buy sandwiches and other ready to eat food at the deli counter. The food is a very good deal. They have some of the best meatballs and Italian sausage. You really need to stop by there for lunch to see the lines of people coming in from across the city to pick up a sandwich. The place is very popular so  call ahead your order and you will not have to wait in line.
GREAT egg sandwiches and very reasonable prices. Will definitely be back again!!

This is definitely your local deli/bodega/food establishment. They serve homemade Italian food ranging from sandwiches to frozen lasagna.  The customer service is very friendly. I wanted to get a meat lasagna, but they didn't have any left. Only cheese. So instead, I ordered the italian beef sandwich instead. I finished that sandwich real quick, but I was a bit disappointed by the lack of flavor and heat from the hot peppers. I had to add my own to taste something.  I'll come back and try their italian ice next time.

Fiore's is on the cusp of full greatness for me, ie 4.5 stars. Still, that doesn't negate the fact that this place is one of those wonderful hidden gems that exist around Chicago.  Appearances are completely deceiving as well. You walk in and you'd think that it's some random bodega. But, oh you'd be wrong. They have a lot of pre-made stuff in the freezers. And guess what, it's all awesome. I bought some meat lasagne, tiramisu, and cannolis. Even frozen and reheated, the lasagne was absolutely killer. I also ended up destroying the 3 cannolis I bought. Thankfully I was able to hold myself to having the tiramisu over two days.  It's a bit out of the way for me, but I shall return. Mostly because I need to grab some sandwiches from here. Well, that and the italian food was awesome.

I love this place. They make great subs to order - you can call your order in - and they also sell amazing cold cuts and salads. Yummy!  I found this place by mistake and went in to grab some bread. I noticed that they had subs galore - even the pepper and egg sub I used to eat a lot when I lived outside NYC in New Jersey. Ba-da-bing!  I am a mortadella addict. I love the big round roll of mortadella. Now there are all sorts of fancy meat places selling fancy mortadella, but no matter how rich I get I will never be too good for the super giant wheel sized mortadella ( this is the theme of advertisements in Italia for "Stella" mortadella). Yep, I get a sub, and a pound of mortadella to go. Whadaboutit?  There is a little section in the back if you want to eat your sub in the shade. Just an awesome place all around. I love the cute mural on the side. The bread is good, but I think the bread is a little better down on Grand Ave., but this place is closer to my house so it is my new home for Italian subs baby!

This place has consistently held their 5 star rating with me. Extremely friendly service (the young guy who makes the sandwiches is beyond friendly but not in an annoying way at all) and the food is just fab. Love love love this little deli.
You must try the pepper & egg and steak sandwiches. Actually they are all really good.

I was introduced to Fiore's by a co-worker of mine.  He eats from this deli every single day, and I cannot blame him.  Fiore's is a GEM!  The environment is that of a wonderful mom & pop shop.  The service is always friendly.  The food?  The food is great and super fresh.  The soups are delicious, the sides are even better, and the sandwiches are a steal!  I have now become hooked.

Thank you Yelp for bringing Fiore's into my life by bringing to the 12-days of Yelpiness event.  It was then that I was hooked..and now the love affair has begun.  It's not like there aren't other places that make subs...there are, but these are special  - made with fresh ingredients, great bread and an abundance of choices. But then there are so many other items to choose from...my head was spinning...do I want a hot or cold sub, do I want some pasta to heat up now? frozen for later? how about a spinach and cheeze panzarotti? do I need some fresh produce while I am here?  And the desserts, AY DIOS MIO THE DESSERTS, can I just say that the little tray I took home of Tiramisu is a little deceiving container of creamy goodness!! On my next trip it will be my mission to Fiore's to conquer the bigger size...and to the Canolli...look out, I have my eye on you and your chocolate covered brother!! Prices cannot be beat...I mean seriously I can't say enough how affordable this place is not just in terms of quality, but just because it is!!  Heck, they even had a sale on a gallon of milk for $1.99 when we were there - WHAA???   Oh how jealous am I that I don't have Fiore's closer to me...I mean like walking distance...*sigh*  But I will nag my boyfriend, take the bus, or even walk when the weather is nice out and I finally decide to exercise, because Fiore's is THAT good! The people who work there are so sweet, very nice helpful, patient and don't judge me for looking like a total geek (at least not to my face).  I seriously would walk out with half the store if I could - I look like a total moroon just staring at everything trying to make a decision.  But I never feel rushed, if anything they just help the next person and just leave me be.... thank you.  :-)    Can u tell I like this place??

Maybe I should stop making fun of my cat. Gretel, bless her little beating heart, is not an usual cat. She's clumsy, has no sense of balance whatsoever and is - above all - so slow you could swear that her mom had a short, but productive love-story with a sloth. In a word, she takes her time to be disgraceful. I would say - like pet, like owner. I have been living in the 'hood for 19 months now, and passed Fiore's 4724 times during my weekly runs. Never stopped. Always considered. But never did. And then last Saturday, I read the words "pepper and egg sandwich" and suddenly, couldn't wait to get my hands on one. It was a pressing matter; I even forgot to put socks in my rubber boots - which was really not a good idea. And..... MEATBALLS entered in my life. A 7-inch sub for $5. Big and juicy, spicy, cheesy, it was perfection on bread. I am seriously thinking about it all the time. Obsessively. I might be addicted. And I don't care.

This long-winded glutton is going to keep this one short... Best meatball sandwich in the city. Best pepper and egg sandwich in the city. Cheap. Delicious. This is a destination for those looking for a great Italian-style sandwich, prepared foods and even pizza puffs. That's right, this place makes their own pizza puffs, and they are 100x better than the ones featured at your old high school's cafeteria. Run here, now.

Maybe I'm judging early, but so far, so good.  I just had the turkey sub from here, and it rates up there with the best I've had in the city so far.  I also bought the lasagna, but haven't tried it yet.  I will definitely be back for another sandwich in the near future. Now made my tops list of best subs in Chicago.  In no particular order: Bari Granddaddy Fiore J.P. Graziano

Fiore's Deli is me and my boyfriend's go-to place on Sunday afternoons for subs, sloppy joes, side salads, meats, cheeses, homemade pastas and of course italian cookies/pastries. We usually buy all of that there. Their prices beat Dominick's, Jewel and Whole Food's prices. There are usually the same people working there every week who are friendly and who take care of you quickly. This place is perfect for a quick, on-the-go meal when you don't want Subway or Jimmy Johns.

I love this place! Best sandwiches in the city.  Thanks for the same day catering order!! I had to help feed 25 people at the last minute for a party. I called them and they had my order ready in 30 minutes!  Thanks guys!

i bought a tub of homemade giardiniera and it did not dissapoint. i have never felt this way about a sandwich before. i love you fiores. your meatballs. your mozzarella. your bread. your marinera.  delightful.

Boyfriend is training, running hard, burning calories.  He eats more than anything I've ever seen... He eats Alfredo sauce (and sometimes cheesecake too) nightly. Witnesses can attest to his phenomenal metabolic capacity... His stepmother found out that I cook, praised every deity she knew of and a few she made up on the fly because this man can EAT!  My old Italian Great-Aunts would weep in joy at the way this man can eat cutlets like flapjacks, pasta like water and still have room for dessert. Speaking of dessert, oh my tiramisu, Have you seen the goods in the cases here?  On a whim, Boyfriend noticed the festive painted storefront and brought me here.   I bought cheese (two kinds!), butter, eggs, fresh french bread crumbs, meat, ten pounds of potatoes, peppers, fragrantly fresh basil, garlic, onions, sausage, milk, canned San Marzano tomatoes...  It totaled just over $50- a STEAL! PS- What is with the bad reviews? Frank behind the counter was a charmer, the deli selection was far cheaper than Jewel and the produce vastly superior too! Boyfriend will bring me back for sure. I can't wait to try the sandwiches next time... of course that is after the three sauces I made and the stack of cutlets are consumed. I think I made enough to feed him thru Thursday...  I admit I found the non-food items overpriced, but who the H-e-double hockey sticks is buying Tampons that sit on a shelf next to Insecticides anyway?!?

How on earth have I never written a review?  I have been going here for at least 8 years. I come here mainly for one thing:  Hot Italian Sausage.  I probably get a pound at least every other week.   I also love their Caprese sandwich - their mozzarella is always super crazy fresh.  Great deli, too!

I have always driven by and wanted to stop, but it has either been closed or I didn't have the time-today, I finally made it in and I am sooooo glad I did. First of all, ordered a couple deli sandwiches from their wide array of choices-got the Italian beef and Italian deli; both were DELICIOUS-super fresh, super good. I also got the olive salad and it, too, was great. Secondly, both the man working the deli counter and the woman working the cash register were just as nice as could be and made me love the store all the more. The woman pointed out all of the homemade dishes in their freezers and assured me once I tasted any of the goodies I bought, I'd be back. She was absolutely right-I like shopping at the small neighborhood places and Fiore's has DEF won me over. Good food, good people, good value!

The Italian Beef sandwich is amazing! Get it with fresh mozzarella and you'll think you're in heaven.  I'm assuming that everything else there is amazing in the sandwich department, but I wouldn't know because I can't bring myself to NOT order the Italian Beef every time I'm there - best I've ever had.  The sweets are great too!
Edit my previous post, they got rid of the attitude and now I am more than happy to have lunch there !! The Italian beef is delicious and don't forget the giardinera!!

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE.  This place is amazing - from its salads, to produce to homemade pasta and deserts. Fiore's never disappoints.  My husband is infatuated with the pepper and egg sammy, I am enamored with their tirimisu.  They also cater - super bonus.
Want an Egg, cheese, and bacon sandwich when you've had one too many drinks the night before? Look no further...for $5, Fiore's hits the spot. It's so large -- you could probably even share it!

Omg...this deli has everyhting...I mean everything.  I have tried everything on their menu.  They have the best meatball sandwiches....I always order berfore I go though only because I hate waiting.  I would definitley have them cater for my next event!!!!  Fiore's I love you!!!!

This place is the truth.  For around 5 bucks you can get an Italian sub or a pepper and egg sandwich that could only be classified as that fishscale.  The back patio serves as the perfect backdrop to enjoy your meal and its picturesque beauty is only rivaled by the signature room. I have only been twice (in the two weeks I have been aware of its existence) and look forward to trying some of their Italian prepared meals or some gelato  Unlike other legit Italian deli's in the area, you won't chip your teeth on the bread here.  Settle for everything and hit this place up.

This place has some delicious food and great prices.  If you are looking for some real quality ingredients such as prosciutto or olives for dinner parties and don't want to pay high prices this is a great find.  The parking situations couldn't be better.  This a great neighborhood place.  They also have a lot of staple ingredients that might save you a trip to the grocery store and make sandwiches and pizza to order for a quick meal. I do agree with the reviewers who said some of the products are a little past their prime.  This tends to happen in smaller places with less turn over.  The mascarpone I bought went bad pretty fast.  I still stand by the deli items though.  They were good and I didn't find anyone unfriendly there.

what every deli should be. great italian favorites, many homemade and most are locally made as well. the trays of tiramisu are divine -- moist without being soggy with a strong rummy top note. the italian sub with spicy peppers is a favorite, as are the marinated artichokes weighed by the pound. don't forget to get their fresh dough to make your own pizza at home!

What a wonderful asset to the neighborhood!  We wandered into Fiore's because I was looking for some quality ricotta cheese for a homemade lasagne (sorry Dominicks but you suck big time on authentic food of any kind).   Fiore's is best described as part deli, part corner store, part Italian grocery.  They have fantastic homemade frozen ravioli (again, Dominicks - you suck), tasty fresh made subs that were incredibly cheap, and yummy Italian treats that I haven't seen since my Italian elders were still around.  Plus the gelato was divine.  We will be back and we will be back often.

When you get the craving for a real Italian sub, Fiore's must be your spot.  Thinly shaved and very high-quality Italian meats on a soft and chewy roll along with Italian dressing and hot peppers will set your Italian-loving heart aburning, trust me here. A smiling gent who gives you plentiful napkins and who just knew that you wanted to dine alfresco in their darling adjacent patio will make you want to come back every day. Oh, and the menu to take home? It's for when you want a sandwich, are in a hurry, and you can call ahead. Every. Day. I want. If you go for the hot peppers, a cooling, lovely gelato must be your dessert. Only the essential flavors up in here, but they are marvelous. Served atop two kinds of cones or in a dish (my preferred serving style), you will find a tiny piece of Italia tucked into a couple of side streets off the main drag. One eight-inch Italian sub, one cup of gelato (pistachio, of course) and a Diet Coke set us back $10.  In a world of boring sandwiches, Fiore's will have you singing, "That's ammoooooooreeeee..." Ciao, Subway.

cool neighborhood deli/grocer.  all i can comment on is their subs...they're great and custom made fresh.  i did take home some frozen marinara sauce and wasn't a fan as it turned out. there were some other good looking salads and heat n' eat stuff in the deli case.

Fiore's Deli was one of the finds that lured me to Ukranian Village in the first place, and it's one of the gems that has me convinced I live in the best neighborhood in Chicago.     The grocery selection is small, but high-quality.  I stop in for the basics like milk and eggs, and stock up on affordable luxuries like $6 pounds of Italian import coffee and locally-produced gelato.  I bring home their handcrafted meatballs and trays frozen zucchini parmesan when I don't feel like making my own home-cooked meals.   They don't have a lot of produce and it doesn't have a very long shelf life.  It's not my first stop for fresh vegetables (for that I recommend Farmer's Pride around the corner); but in the summer they put the crates outside like a classic green grocer, and the sight of the tomatoes and eggplant lit up in the afternoon sunshine is better than a postcard.

Is it just a sign of the times that prices are going up everywhere?  Why would a breakfast sandwich be so expensive? CAUSE IT'S HUGE!  (that's what she said) It's also super tastyyy. (that's what she said too and she was talking about the sandwich both times) In addition to the sandwiches this is also a tiny market and worth supporting for both reasons.

This place is great--I am glad to live so close to it. It is a full-service deli that serves homemade breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Delicious food, and all the pasta, meatballs, and sausages are homemade by an old italian family that has owned the store for over 30 years. (The owners are frequently on vacation back to Italy to visit family, so you know it's the legit stuff.) In addition, the place has a great selection of just about anything you'd ever need from a convenience store--from food, dessert, chips and cereal to cleaning supplies, batteries, and diapers. To top it all off, they have a good selection of seasonal produce available. And the prices simply cannot be beat! I love getting a huge italian sub for $4.50... SO GOOD!

Have been here several times as this place is just a few steps from my buddies place...oh how I wish it were on my block.  They have it all for a family run corner grocer.  Fresh fruits, veggies, meats, cheeses, peppers, pastas, breads, etc. plus everything else you'd expect from a mom and pop store.  I've never purchased any of their sandwiches but they always look and smell amazing and by the looks of other reviews, i've been missing out.    [x] will be back

such a great place to stop in for a quick bite to eat -- the pepper and egg sandwich is aamazing. please do yourself the favor and order it with cheese and giardinera. it was great,, and good portion size: money ratio. really looking forward to trying the meat sandwiches and desserts,,

This little gem is reminiscent of so many corner ethnic grocery stores that I would now classify as an endangered species. They are fading away into the sunset unless we continue to support those few wonders we have left!  Long before the generic and sanitized 7-11's or the now defunct White Hen's came on the scene. Chicago was peppered with numerous wonderful corner stores such at Fiore's, where home made sausages, salads, where deli meats were hand sliced to order, imported specialty foods and most likely penny candy back in the day.  Today, we want everything shall I say too suburban, generic, modern and safe. ....And what did we end up with, c r a p!   Here Fiorie's offers the best of that old Chicago style corner store that when you enter really smells like something wonderful is happening inside. It's an exciting fragrance of something really cooking!  This is a awesome place to rediscover something old, yet in many cases far better than what we are lead to believe is so wonderfully organic and pure today. Fiore's rocks! This is a family enterprise sells wonderful Italian specialties that are excellent !  It's treasured hard work, family pride and success! I highly recommend Fiore's and any place just like it. It's a great experience to rediscover the past of the best of Chicago today.  I love this place!  It's just so special.

Fiores, how I love thee.  How I love your tuna salad sub.  You are the only deli around that knows how to use hot peppers well, understanding the important role that they play in making a tasty sub.  And, if you're not in the mood for a sub, go for some pasta (individual or group size).  They even sell homemade sauce (marinara and alfredo) to go.  Yes, please.  Before I move onto the produce and detergent that's also available, I will stop.  Just go.

The produce is all suspect, and the bread can be moldy.  The service is, when the young man is working behind the counter, terse and nearly unfriendly.  He would clearly like to be elsewhere.  The sandwiches are good, but I'm just not sure it's worth it.  If the tomatoes in the produce section are suspect, what leads me to believe the ones in the sandwiches aren't?  I would love to support the neighborhood place, but I believe this place gets too much credit because it is just that, a neighborhood place.  The need to get their act together if they want to stay in business.

Not really what I was expecting, but actually it was a very nice surprise.  They have a deli inside of a small convenience store.  The food is really good and the cannoli  and pastries looked and tasted awesome.  Too bad they didn't have a place to sit and eat, but it was just as good at home.

This place is just so damn good.  The genius of a real Italian sub is the quality of the ingredients and the proportions, and the staff at Fiore's select and measure with the proper feeling, cuz they got that true Barese touch.  And it's freaking cheap.  You will not believe how much (exquisite) sandwich you get for the money.  Things like fruit and gum are also cheap here.  What's also nice here is that, in an increasingly homogenized Chicago, this place (which I've been coming to for years) is still just the old-school neighborhood market, where there's little kids running in and out and every once in a while you catch some conversation in Italian.

I wanted to love this place.  I wanted it to be the neighborhood place it should be....it isn't.  While I have tried it over and over again, Fiore's still disappoints as a streetcorner market.  Good, not great sandwiches.  That's it.  I have bought bread from them only to have found that it had expired two days prior to that (my bad for not noticing, but still...), and their fruit and veggies are all suspect.  To top it off, the kid behind the counter who obviously works for the family business, couldn't care less about being at all pleasing.  He is gruff to the point of rude, and would rather be doing something else entirely.  Doesn't make me want to go back....ever. Boo.

Just moved into the hood. And I'm super excited to have found Fiore's! The meatball sandwich is ridiculously good. Order it with provolone and home made giardeniara and you wont regret it. Served on amazing D'Amato's bread and topped with marinara sauce. Delish.  As for the friendliness...I found the staff here to be very friendly! It takes a minute to get your order, but definitely worth the wait. Oh, and upon checking out the guy at the register told me they deliver too! I think I've found my new favorite sandwich place.

One word- GELATO. Only a handful of flavors but a perfect compliment to an Italian (or American) Sandwich. I love this place, the people who work there and the fresh produce on hand. Affordable and delicious! Go here now! Better than Bari if you ask me!

A nice new find in my neighborhood.  Just picked up a sandwich there.  Great Italian bread and only $4.75!  I was blown away by their reasonable prices!!  The price for a pound of turkey was $5.99!!!  That's two dollars LESS than Dominic's.  I'll definitely be back.

When half the shop decides that they all have a craving for a pepper and egg sandwich, it should come to no one's surprise that I came here for a Thursday lunch.  (Props to Fiore's that they have P & E sandwiches every day!)  About $5.50 each for a 9" sandwich, it was inexpensive and so delicious.  I think this could be one of my favorite new (to me) Italian markets.

I used to live right down the street from this place.  Ukranian Village actually used to be an Italian Neighborhood way back when.  Support your local businesses!  We love their homemade pastas, sauces, and breads (Locally made by another bakery).  If you like this, try Bari on Grand also.

seriously delicious lunch. SERIOUSLY. i'm a bread snob.... blame it on a semester abroad in the baguette capital of the world, but a sandwhich must start with a carb base that won't crumble, smuush, or stick to my mouth.  i want the crunch factor followed by the chew factor. fiore's delivers. as for what's inside, i'm not as snooty.... but holy provolone! like butta.  and subway's "$5 footlong" jive can now leave my head because i've discovered the "$4.75 humungo" sammie here. oh yes, that would be their version of "small".   then there's the surroundings.... a tray of freshly made chocolate canoilis coming from the kitchen to the counter, placed next to the sinfully fudgey goodness of the brownies, also sometimes known as "chocolate squares". and the homemade pastas that whisper to you..."i'm delicious! and i was just made this morning! and if you buy me now you won't have to worry about what to eat for dinner!". now here's when, in many establishments reviews, i'd note the fact that the service is crummy or the people are rude... but NOT HERE! they're lovely, warm, friendly and make you feel like you can't wait to become a regular.... even though they already treat you like one!

The Italian sub at Fiore's is the best I've ever had.  If I didn't fear a heart attack at age 30, I would eat that mother every day.  Let me elaborate:  fresh Italian loaf, mortadella, capicola, salami, ham, etc., tomato, oil, and mild hot peppers.  It is so damn good.  I could go for one right now. The family that runs the place is awesome....the mom is a sweetheart, the dad is scary, and the son is pissed (he has his good days when Dad's not there).  It's a sweet joint.
I adore a good sandwich. I've  never had a bad sandwich here. This place is a delicious beacon of sandwich hope shining in the depths of the ukrainian village.

That pepper and egg sandwich is amazing.  I want another one as I type this.  Get it with hot giardiniera, even if you have a low tolerance for spicy foods - you can handle it.  It comes with light fluffy eggs, melted deli-sliced mozzarella cheese, roasted green and red peppers, oil and homemade giardiniera between a loaf of crusty-on-the-outside, soft-on-the-inside french bread baked fresh daily and in-house.  Yes, it's gonna be pretty greasy...but worth it for the deliciousness.  A 9" sandwich at six bucks is plenty to split between two, but tasty enough that you'll probably want your own.

I'm not sure why their eggs are the best I've ever had, but they are. Here's some advice: 1.  Call ahead on weekend afternoons 2.  Avoid the coffee cake 3.  Try the canoli 4.  Go to Bari or Conte Di Savola if you want proscuitto

This little market is right on the way home from the Metra for me, and I totally dig it.  I haven't bought much in the way of dry goods, but they have lots of tasty frozen pasta and sauces for you to take home.  For $9, a lasagna fed the boyfriend and I for dinner + leftovers.  Not a bad deal.   The best part of this store is that they sell locally made gelato.  It's in the freezer in the front and is made by the same company that provides the gelato at Piccolo, Black Dog Gelato.  The chocolate gelato is a little scoop of heaven, let me tell you.  So freaking good - it alone is worth the trip.

A near perfect pepper and egg sandwich at a reasonable price -- I think the 10" is only $5.50.  Get it with giardiniera, in the name of all that is holy.   The fresh mozzarella is excellent and the desserts are good too.  Skip the cannoli and get a slice of chocolate cake instead ("chocolate squares," in the parlance).

A good old school feeling deli...  No fancy labels here, everything is hand written still... The imported selections on the shelves are minimal in comparison to other places nearby (Bari), but there's a decent selection of meats, cheeses, sausages in their deli case.  They also have a freezer full of homemade pastas, lasagnas, alfredo sauce, red sauce, and a number of other things.  I tried the lasagna with spinach and ground beef. It wasn't the best lasagna I've ever had, but consider they freeze it and you just throw it in the oven... It was $9 for a serving size that probably would've fed 3 or 4 for dinner.  (The top had freezer burn).  Not sure how old it was, some things are better off not known (the expiration date said about 5 months from the day I bought it). They have subs and other stuff too.  Cannoli is $1.75 (Chocolate $2) and is OK. They have a nice outdoor patio out back... It's not incredibly obvious that it's for Fiore, but there's a gate that's open on the side and there are nothing but tables in kind of fenced in area.

Hit or miss experience. Often their shelf-stable pantry items are close to or past their expiration dates.  I've purchased packages that were infested with weevils.  I attribute those both to a slow turnover on some of their products.  You're better off sticking to the stuff they make on-site and avoiding the small grocery section altogether, no matter how convenient it might seem at the time.   The people working there run the gamut from extremely friendly to downright rude.  I've felt, at times, that ordering a sub was an imposition on them.  I've lived in the neighborhood for three years and there are still folks there that act like they've never seen me before.  I'd hoped to be rewarded for my loyalty to them with a little pleasanter a customer experience.  C'mon folks, would it kill you to acknowledge me when I come in or to not grumble when I order a sandwich?  I think not.

Carmela is a doll!  I was running around Chicago's finer gourmet places and better known Italian import  places in search of the elusive green peppercorns for a special my chef wanted to feature.  I called her and not only did she go digging on a Saturday afternoon for me, she held them for me until I got there and then offered to find her supplier and order them for me in bulk.  After all that I found some of their house made pastas for sale in the freezer and picked up a few and had my guys whip them up and let me tell you they are fabulous!  Totally made with love, only the way an Italian woman can!   Seriously, they were so good and she is so "simpatico" I want to see if she will make some specialty pastas for me because they were FANTASTIC.  Store is just a little old school corner market but people were lined up at the deli counter getting sandwiches made to order.  I love this place and am so grateful to have found them!  Thank you Yelp!  Grazie Carmela!

This place is definitely a gamble.  I used to work close by, and for the first month I think I had a prosciutto sandwich everyday.  Because they were delicious, and also because I was trying to figure out what day the bread for their subs got delivered to their store.  (My investigation concluded Wednesday, but it could've changed since then.)  There were times I had an incredibly stale bread, but dared not say anything to the man, or "dad" running the show up front.  (Did you notice the metal bat behind the counter?  I, for one, do not want to find out why they keep it there.) I'd also walk in and grab a drink instead of ordering if I saw the "son" working behind the deli counter.  His sandwiches were the worst.  Not only were they poorly constructed, (all the meat jammed on one end and the lettuce on the other) but I could swear there was an aftertaste of bitterness and contempt. Then there was the other time I raved about their egg and pepper sandwiches to my friends at work, only to get BURNT scrambled eggs in all our sandwiches!  The eggs were literally gray and inedible... I didn't understand how you can mess that up.  I complained, (over the phone) and got three free replacement sandwiches the next time I ordered.   Oh-- and their "Homemade Clam Chowder" looks suspiciously like Campbell's Chunky Clam Chowder...  I've heard other horror stories from my old co-workers, but for some reason we keep coming back for more.  Probably cuz when it's good, it's damn good. The "mom" is a doll!  I miss her friendly face on my lunchbreaks now.  FYI - If you're planning on getting deli sandwiches for lunch, I'd call in my order, the line can get pretty long and they're made to order.

Fiore's is the best place for subs in the UKV. The variety is great and the deli is *packed to the gills* with italian groceries, fresh produce, homemade frozen items, and even household stuff in the back.

Has Bari met it's match? No.  But they make a damn good italian sub.  It's closer to my house and it's easy to park and run in for take out.  I gave them a call about 3 minutes before I got there and they had my sandwich made up and ready to go.  2% milk was on sale for $2.89 a gallon.  Not bad.  I'm sitting at home wishing I had picked up a canoli -- they looked sooo good.   I will be the first to admit it's not the cleanest looking joint in the city but their food is really good.  I've heard the homemade italian sausage is great - that will be my next purchase.
I live right around the corner so this is my "neighborhood" market but if I didn't live in the 'hood, I'd make the trek for the deli sandwiches, they're the best.

Fiore's is a sweet little corner deli and specialty grocery shop on the corner of Oakley and Erie. I drive by it every morning on the way to work after dropping off the children.  Here is what I HAVE experienced: Aisles packed with imported and domestic specialty Italian treats, ingredients, and other products.  Deli case jampacked with olives, salads, cheeses, and meats. The same woman with the same big smile on her face every time I go in to order a sandwich for lunch. The only time she didn't smile was when she was crying because she had to put her dog down.  Frowning young man behind the cash register. Never says two words. Not rude, just not friendly. Delicious bread - by far better than Jimmy John's, Potbelly's, or any other corporate sub/sandwich shop. For Lent - egg and pepper sandwich every Friday. Here is what I have NOT experienced: Roaches Roach feces Roach-infested food Evidence of roaches Rudeness Nothing worthy of an all CAPS review, that's for sure.

When I walked in, looked up behind the register, and saw a framed picture of Padre Pio, the same picture that every old Italian relative of mine has hanging in their houses, I knew I was in the right place. There is a small deli counter that makes delicious sandwiches.  I got a prosciutto and provolone sammy, and it was loaded with prosciutto.  Real prosciutto.  Delicious prosciutto.  Prosciutto that costs me upwards of $12 a pound if I buy it at a deli.  I ate it in their little back sitting area outside, which was really a good early-fall experience.  So peaceful I forgot I was in the middle of the city for a second.  So tasty I decided to have a cannolo afterwards, which again did not disappoint. The grocery section was great too, full of little Italian thingies that I grew up eating.  The only bad thing was that I didn't have a bag with me, so I had no way to carry home on my bike all the groceries that I wanted to bring back. I guess that just means I'll have to come back.  Often.  Mmmm...

i think this place is better than bari. for one reason and one reason only. their bread doesnt cut up my mouth. its soft and pillowy. i should know. i sleep on fiore's bread. FIORE'S! and they have homemade breadsticks and tiramisu and you dont have to deal with a-holes. however, bari does have portobellos for way cheap. whatever. i am so over it. no im not ill go to FIORES for sandwiches and pizza and sloppy joes. but ill probs go to bari for produce. ok now im over it.

Personally, I have no clue about health code or cockroaches, but I do know they carry imported Italian pastas you can't get at the regular grocery stores, specifically my favorite anellini!  There will be no awards for friendliness for some of the people in the store, but it is in walking distance, it is tucked away, and it has some tasty stuff you can't find elsewhere, which gets it four stars in my book.  For five stars some friendliness would have to be shown and the sandwiches would have to consistently have fresh bread.

I love this place and the people.  Great sandwiches.  When I first moved to this neighborhood I felt like I'd been dropped on another planet.  They rolled out the welcome wagon and started buying things for me that I buy all the time that were not for sale anywhere else in the neighborhood.  This is a small family run business with personal warm friendly service, great food and good hours.  I rec. them all the time.

Right on the corner of Erie and Oakley, this place has good sandwiches and great cannolis. Mmmmm...cannolis...*drools*  Also, this place has great ingredients for making pizza. All items are fresh and taste great. Man, I could totally go for some pizza right about now.

This small, family-run, corner market sells the best fresh mozzarella cheese in the city. The canoli ain't bad either, though I have a feeling they get it from D'mato's Bakery, which is nearby. Fiore's also carries fresh vegables, herbs, some dairy, and a few other grocery items. They have a full deli counter, which features a nice selection of Italian cheeses, meats, and salads.
